abstract.t: This document describes the Universal Voting Markup Language (UVML), a syntax that augments conventional text communications with a structured representation of opinion. UVML consists of two top-level elements: ballot and query. UVML enables voters to cast ballots (text, image, or video) that can be reliably interpreted by either human readers or automated-agents. In addition to one or more votes, UVML-ballots may also contain the voter's demographic signature. A voter can use UVML-queries to retrieve voting results and audit sample ballots over varying time frames, with the option of these being filtered by voter demographics. The design of UVML leverages cross-cultural sentiment and voting-systems scholarship.
